Award.AwardTitle: Subseafloor Observatory Science in the Nankai Trough: Analysis of Earthquakes and Hydraulic Transients, and Installation of a Community Borehole Facility
Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal seeks to analyze pore pressure data from a borehole in the Nankai subduction complex (site C0002), to develop an interactive portal to disseminate data from this borehole, and to ?shepherd? the installation of new borehole instrumentation at Nankai. The pore pressure data will be analyzed in concert with seismic and strain measurements in an effort to provide a direct correlation between pore pressure and seismic strain. The new portal will be connected to a cabled system (DONET) and will make all borehole data available to the wider community in real time. The new community instrumented borehole will span a splay fault in hole C0010 and also be connected to the cabled system, providing real-time access to data.

Broader impacts: The new data portal will be integrated with an existing system already in classroom use at Penn State, allowing undergraduates access to the real-time data sets. The work will provide information regarding the behavior of potential tsunamigenic faults. The work is international in scope and highly leveraged by international funds.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on analysis of data from a borehole observatory situated directly above the earthquake-generating reaches of the subduction megathrust fault offshore SW Honshu, Japan. The observatory instrumentation was deployed in 2010 using the drillship D/V Chikyu, and includes continuous measurement of strain accumulation and release in the rock mass down to ~1 km beow the seabed associated with: (1) gradual interseismic loading between great (Magnitude 8-class) earthquakes that strike the region every ~100-150 yr; (2) dynamic shaking from distant large and moderate sized earthquakes; (3) potential slow slip events wherein a portion of accumulated stress is relieved along to plate boundary fault below; and (4) additional hydrological and tidal perturbations that provide insights into the physical properties of the rock. These responses were monitored through measurement of pore fluid pressure in the formation (funded by this NSF project), and complementary measurements of tilt, volumetric strain, and seismicity (funded by JAMSTEC). In 2013, the borehole was connected to a real-time cabled observatory network, allowing instantaneous and real-time transmission of the formation conditions. Some of the key outcomes and discoveries of the project include:

1) Identification of a slow slip event and associated low-frequency earthquakes alont the Nankai subduction megathrust that immediately followed the M9 Tohoku mega-quake. This event lasts for ~2 days, and our initial interpretation is that is was triggered by the passage of dynamic waves from the Tohoku event ~900 km away. Our detailed analysis of this event is ongoing. 

2) Documentation of a clear pattern in which hydrologic responses to nearby earthquakes depends on their distance and magnitude. The threshold size for events to generate a response increases with distance, and follows a trend close to that previously documented for other hydrologic phenomena assoaited with earthquakes on land (e.g., water level changes, changes in streamflow, and activity of mud volcanoes).

3) Documentation of clear pressure increases in response to nearby drilling activity at a new borehole ~110 m away. These responses (a) yielded key insight into the rock formation's fluid flow and strength properties; and (b) provided serendipitous and new constraints on the stress conditions in the newly drilled hole that permitted fluids to escape and propagate to the observatory. 

A major part of the project, in addition to analysis of the observatory measurements, was to develop and maintain a web site to serve as a portal for visualization and dissemination of the data. The site is synchronized with the master server in Japan every 10 minutes, and provides a user-friendly portal for users to view and download selected periods of the dataset (http://offshore.geosc.psu.edu), scroll through the data, and provides a platform for undergraduate students at Penn State to highlight, describe, and link notable events such as earthquakes, slow slip events, or perturbations related to nearby drilling (e.g., Figure 1).
